ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Historical analysis, essay writing, argument formation for skills. Knowledge wise, a comprehensive history of Egypt and its surrounding lands.
Ancient Egypt knowledge
A broad understanding of the complex history of egypt
I learned how Egyptian culture continues to show up in our world today.
everything ancient egypt- culture, environment, change over time, art
Egypt history
I learned a ton about ancient Egyptian history in a way that I have never before! I also learned how to effectively analyze primary sources.
Learned more about ancient Egypt
I developed a broad understanding of the political, religious, militaristic, and cultural background of Egypt and its neighboring nations from the predynastic to the Ptolemaic.
I learned a broad and overarching history of Ancient Egypt, including key events, pharaohs, architecture, and religion. The essays also provided some experience in history research.
I learned a ton about Ancient Egypt and the contemporary context that is has in the modern world
How to evaluate ancient Egyptian concepts over centuries and in the context of one another

This class goes over the history of Egypt, from the unification sometime in the 3200-3000s B.C.E., to the conquering by the Romans. We learned about the history through the study of primary sources, acknowledging both what the primary sources tell us about history and also what we can't know from them. A focus is placed on understanding the biases that come from many of the sources, and cross examining various written accounts with each other and with archeological evidence.
A ton of basic knowledge about ancient Egypt. I have a lot of knowledge about why they grew and why they fell.

Over the course of this class, I have developed the skills to critically analyze various cultural materials, literary sources, and artistic representations to piece together the beginning of a civilization. This course has given me the insights to understand the meaning of various depictions of Egyptian rulers and the events that took place under the reign in the context of the larger time period and historical development of Egypt as a whole. I also developed a healthy understanding of the timeline and history of Egypt from the 3000 BCE to 31 BCE.
solid understanding of ancient egypt

In this course, I learned many fascinating facts about Ancient Egypt. This course also challenged my historical analysis and writing skills. I am confident that I left this course as a better student than when I entered.

I was able to look at various perspectives of ancient Egyptian history and understand the way that it can be corrupted by the people writing about it. I also learned about how intricate the different aspects of a culture can be and how they relate to our much more advanced civilisations to date. We have much to learn about perseveration and from the religions of the ancient Egyptians.

I developed skills in analyzing artifacts from Ancient Egypt, writing analytically about Ancient Egyptian history, and learned about historical events and the culture of different Ancient Egyptian dynasties.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Huge strength is the teaching. Both Professors and all the TAs massively improved the courseso much so I'm considering taking more of their courses. No weaknesses.
The lecture style is not very conducive to learning, I prefer slides with bullet points over two professors jumping from topic to topic randomly
No weaknesses. Great course.

I think the lectures could be a little more structured, just because sometimes I struggled to get down information properly and understand where we were in time. However, I think the sections were structured very well.

strengths: like the dialogue/conversational style of lecture, weaknesses: little incentive to pay much attention to lectures because we didn't need to know any of the material for the class assignments
Like the format, needs to be more structured

I find Egyptian/ ancient history fascinating, so I found the course generally very interesting. Sometimes, the lectures seemed a bit disorganized. I think the class should focus more on the chronology of ancient Egypt in the beginning, and then shift towards the end to be more about broader concepts uch as 'environment'. I felt like I learned a lot that would have been helpful to know earlier in the course as i was studying for the exam, so I think it would maybe be better structured with a midterm exam and a final essay or project as opposed to essays and then a final exam.
In lectures I would've liked the profs to talk more about things that showed up on the final rather than just having conversations for lecture

The TAs are a very good strength of the class. They are always available to explain the content in more depth, review your assignments, and help prepare for exams. I thought the more conversational lectures were a little bit of a weakness because it made it difficult to understand all of the content, leading to a lot of extra preparation for the final.
Ability to understand an ancient civilization is very different than studying more modern history, this is achieved in this course
The course was a bit too broad/somewhat too much information to cover in one semester to go in depth

Weaknesses: Lectures were a bit disorganized. However, very interesting. Relatively lower workload
Strengths: the TA's 100000%! They were amazing, always willing to answer questions and stay after for help. They recognize how disorganized this class is and tried their best to make up for the shortcomings of the class. Huge shout out to Jasmine who organized a 4-hour study break, Camille for 6 hours of study session (w/ Olive the best dog ever! & homemade cookies), and Georgia for her 5 hour study session. They were amazing and really helped for the exam.

The strengths of this course is numerous with phenomenal TAs, professors, and interesting and intriguing course content. The lectures were engaging as the professors delved into their work and explained their findings in the context of the topic of the class. They provided numerous insights and minor factoids to pique students' interest throughout the broader themes, a tool that worked. The only weakness is the lack of organization at times during the lecture due to the spontaneity of the professors, yet this was not intrinsically bad.
Too much to cover to really get in depth on anything
The class was very organized and engaging.

This course was very strong in its individual engagement as there were opportunities every week to ask the professors specific questions that they would answer at the end of every lecture. Also, the TA's were extremely engaged and beneficial to the course as they were extremely fast with their communication and the discussion sections often consisted of very educational and engaging activities to help us understand what was happening in lecture that week.

This course is taught by two professors, both of whom seem to be unwilling to create actual lectures and instead ramble for 50 minutes twice a week. The TFs are excellent, but their role is largely to make up for a lack of investment on the part of the instructors themselves. The professors' lack of investment was made more evident when neither were in attendance for the final exam (the TFs were left to proctor the exam). The TFs were fantastic, but I would struggle to recommend this course without knowing that the TFs would be returning, as they are the only reason the course was able to run.

The subject material of the course and its sections are interesting, and the essays practice different skills (artifact essay, historical analysis essay) which was helpful. I appreciated how the course had an archaeological, literary, and historical lens when approaching the history of pharaonic Egypt.
The course could be further improved by integrating more of the details from readings and topics necessary for exams/essays directly into lectures.

I felt the course of was disorganized and I struggled to connect the class content. I enjoyed the course material and the emphasis on different research methods like historical sources vs. archeology.

Strengths: All of the professors and TAs were very passionate. The course taught me a lot about ancient Egypt.
Weakness: The course lacked cohesiveness. Lectures focused on primary sources that professors thought were cool, instead of themes. This discouraged student engagement.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 100%. The content and teaching is among the best I've had at Yale.
Absolutely. Great class and great professors.
Yes, because it is an interesting class you might not get to take otherwise.
if looking for a fifth class it's not bad. Can be pretty dry sometimes but profs are nice and wasn't too much work
Not really, most of what you learn is on your own
Yes, if they are interested in ancient Egyptian history.
Yes, interesting but have to be intrinsically motivated to learn outside of class to be successful.
This is a great 5th class, easy humanities credit, or an interesting gut. The exam requires some preparation, but is not challenging, and all of the assignments are very reasonable. Highly recommend!
yes
Yes, absolutely. It is a very cool part of history that everyone should know.
Yes the material is interesting and not too hard
Yes! The content is so interesting and the workload is lower.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. It was fascinating and gave a history of Ancient Egypt in a fascinating and almost conversational way that kept students very interested and engaged. I also appreciated the ability to be creative with our assignments, which were often open ended and allowed us to research what we wanted and write about any topic that interested us in the context of Ancient Egypt.
Yes, this class is very interesting, and well structured for learning.
Yes, the professers engaged in good conversation during lecture and were enthusiastic
Absolutely. It was a very well-structured course.

I would highly recommend this course to another student because of the interesting content and history of Egypt and the unique opportunity to explore the various artistic depictions during these time periods along with special events the TFs plan for their sections.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student even if they aren't a history major because of how interesting and collaborative the class is.
I think it varies in how seriously one would take the course. If they are truly interested in ancient history or Egypt specifically then this course would be an excellent opportunity for them
The course is easy. If you want an easy A, then yes this course is for you. If you actually want to learn about Ancient Egypt, this course is not for you.

I would recommend this course to other students who are interested in Ancient Egyptian history and learning more about archaeology and/or the formation of ancient civilizations. The course was both interesting and informative.
I would recommend this course because of the content and it is more relaxed, but I would warn them against the course structure and teaching style.

Yes! I learned a lot about ancient Egypt and found myself more interested than I actually expected. However, you need a lot of discipline for this class because of a lot of learning falls on you to read the textbook (lectures didn't really give information, just looked at cool pictures).
